title: gordon taylor ruined footballers reputation coronavirus
story: WE live in an age of heroes – when every day brings acts of kindness, courage and humanity that shine like a light among the darkness.The nation unites every Thursday night at pm to applaud the doctors, nurses and carers who put their lives on the line every time they go to work.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updates But there are other unsung heroes, working in low-paid jobs, that leave them exposed while the rest of us are safe at home.I think of the cleaners who go into those hospitals every day.Our bin men are heroes, too. And the bus drivers — nine already dead in London alone from Covid-. And the pharmacists filling out prescriptions in tiny, windowless shops.And the postmen, delivery drivers, papergirls — and anonymous neighbours who put notes through doors offering help for the vulnerable.And the supermarket workers who stack the shelves to keep our nation fed. And a round of applause for our Queen,  this month, who gave the speech of a letime last Sunday — and for our Prime Minister who ended up in intensive care.From the bin men to Boris, we are surrounded by heroes — but the one glaring exception has been elite football.Despite inidual acts of heroism, such as Manchester United’s Marcus Rashford raising £million for underprivileged schoolkids, football has not covered itself in glory during this national emergency.On Wednesday, Premier League captains announced they were banding together to create a fund to raise millions for the NHS.This is a big-hearted gesture but can’t hide the fact that for much of this health crisis the national game has been hopelessly out of touch with the national mood.When the Prime Minister was seriously ill, it made the skin crawl to see whining millionaire footballers resisting pay cuts from clubs that have nothing to sell, no revenue coming in and no idea when football will begin again.Gordon Taylor, the £million-a-year chief of the Professional Footballers Association, has made his members about as popular as bankers.While the country fights for its le, Taylor has fought for the rights of loafing footballers to keep every last million. He has badly misjudged the moment, as have the clubs owned by billionaires who have furloughed their tea ladies while pampered footballers continue to earn up to £, a week.It has been embarrassing to see hypocritical footballers mistaking “lockdown” for “lock-in”, acting like the new rules do not apply to them.After previously urging fans to stay at home, Aston Villa’s Jack Grealish emerged bleary-eyed from an all-night party and pranged his -grand Range Rover.Manchester City’s Kyle Walker had a couple of escort girls delivered to his door, soon before telling the peasants to social distance and save lives and blah-blah-blah. All that stuff about washing your hands, Kyle — should that be before or after the escorts have been round And Spurs manager Jose Mourinho oversaw a training session on Hadley Common, for all the world asthere was one rule for the princes of football and one for the plebs who pay their wages.Do the fatheads of football ever watch the news Mass unemployment is coming. Many of the millions about to be chucked on the dole will be football fans. So how the hell can football — the players, clubs, PFA — continue to kid themselves the bubble they exist in has not already burst The world has changed.There should be no more all-night parties, no more escort girls and no more car prangs. Like it or not, footballers are role models and many will follow their lead.Troy Deeney, Watford captain and one of the prime movers behind the Players Together fund, defends Jack Grealish’s busy social le during the time of lockdown. “What’s he going to do ” Troy asked. “Sit in the yard on his own ”Yes, Troy — because that’s what millions are doing right now. Shocking, I know, but the new rules apply to footballers, too.Most footballers come from working-class backgrounds but too many of them have a sense of entitlement worthy of Marie Antoinette.Look what happened to her.NEVER going out is placing an unbearable strain on relationships.So it is nice to see that Camila Morrone, , and Leonardo DiCaprio, , seem to be happily self-isolating together.I was afraid Leo might decide Camila’s just too old for him.STEVE HEDLEY, rail union fat cat at the RMT, boasts that he would “throw a party”Boris Johnson died of coronavirus – and hopes “the whole Cabinet of Tory b******s” also become victims.If Hedley was on a ventilator fighting for his le, would he check how the doctors and nurses caring for him voted at the last election You don’t think those NHS heroes all voted Labour, do you, Steve WILLIAM and Kate carried out their first virtual royal duty this week, thanking teaching staff who look after the children of key workers.I have never seen smiles that wide on the faces of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge.I am sure that, deep down inside, they are really missing Harry and Meghan.They are just covering it up really well.FAREWELL Honor Blackman, who has died at the age of , immortal for ever in her career-defining role as Pussy Galore in Goldfinger.It is funny how certain names fall out of favour.At school I had mates called Keith and Ian, but nobody is called Keith or Ian today.Same thing with Pussy Galore. Bond girls just don’t get called things like Pussy Galore any more.THIS lockdown is taking an enormous toll on jobs, education and mental health but most of us understand it is necessary.I am infuriated, though, by the constant threats to intensy the lockdown, including closing the parks,a handful of idiots continue to flout the rules.Health Secretary Matt Hancock rages that he finds it “unbelievable that people are not staying at home” – and threatens to ban all exercise.Personally, I find it unbelievable that Hancock makes threats like some little home counties Hitler.Give credit to the MILLIONS who are doing their best during the lockdown.Don’t threaten the decent majority with a punishment beating because a selfish minority break the rules.If this Government ramps up the lockdown they will lose the British people. And something will explode.If some morons can’t stick to the rules, punish THEM – not the rest of us.KILLING EVE lost its way when the show’s creator Phoebe “Fleabag” Waller-Bridge bailed out after the first series. The second series was painfully naff.Early reports on the third series, starting tomorrow on BBC iPlayer, are not promising.But Jodie Comer as Russian assassin Villanelle will always make you want to tune in. Evenit is just for her new outfits.THIS global catastrophe started in China.When the dead are buried and we stand among our ruined economies, there MUST be some kind of reckoning.After World War Two, the Potsdam Conference decided that Germany should pay billion for what Germany had inflicted on humanity.China is now boasting that le is back to normal there, while we are burying NHS nurses like Rebecca Mack, , who worked in a children’s cancer unit. She has been hailed as a “wonderful daughter” by her heartbroken parents.Coronavirus was not an act of God. It started in China.A study by  senior Tories concludes that the UK should pursue China through international courts for £billion in coronavirus compensation.Germany paid for starting the war. Why shouldn’t China pay for coronavirus GREAT news that Boris is out of intensive care and on the way to recovery.But when he emerges from that ICU, he must give himself all the time it takes to fully recover.And then Boris has to lose weight. I saw David Cameron describe Boris as “very fit”.Sorry – a -year-old man who weighs over st is emphatically not “very fit”.He is a serious illness – a heart attack, stroke or diabetes – waiting to happen.I know from having Boris as my neighbour for years that he loves his jogging and cycling. But please slim down, Boris.Carrie and your unborn child need you. So does Dilyn the dog. So does your country.Because Boris Johnson’s great genius is for giving people HOPE.God knows we need some of that right now. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady take responsibility lockdown
story: My goodness, aren’t we lucky to have the Queen, whose speech last Sunday was pitch-perfect. It was a magnicent address, from a magnicent woman.Her experience and serenity did more to calm and inspire the nation than anything  I can think of as this crisis has unfolded.Best of all, she reminded us that there will be le beyond this lockdown — that we will meet again.If we just focus on the here and now, we won’t be able to prepare for the future beyond the virus.But it’s also true that none of us can think straight when we are in the eye of the storm.That is where good leadership comes in. It helps us all to hold strong, not to go to pieces and to stick to the guidance given to us.Everyone looks to the leader to make decisions, and it’s the decisions we make that will chart our way out of the crisis.Unfortunately, after the Queen’s address to the nation came the news that Prime Minister Boris Johnson had been admitted to hospital intensive care.At that point, anyone who was in any doubt this illness did not discriminate was forced to reconsider.At the time of writing, Boris was back on a regular hospital ward. But his illness has been a reminder that any of us are susceptible to Covid-.Most people are shocked he is in hospital and sympathise with his pregnant girlfriend Carrie Symonds.But of course it has raised the question: Who is really in chargehe is not  Without leadership, we all get distinctly uneasy.We all have leaders in our lives. We are all looking towards them to show us what to do and lead us through it.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealSome companies have stepped up to the plate and are doing good things — reassuring their staff, treating people well and doing their utmost to make sure people will be paid. Some aren’t, of course. But good bosses are taking pay cuts and doing everything they can to keep their businesses alive and look after their staff.At West Ham United we continue to pay all our full and part-time staff  per cent of their wages.My financial director, my manager and I have all taken a  per cent reduction to make sure this happens.It’s when there’s a crisis like this that we see who is made of what.Boris’s temporary stand-in, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab, while talking about the PM’s hospital admission, referred to him as his boss, his colleague, but also his friend.Respect and friendship are the key words when it comes to good leadership.A good leader makes the tough decisions because they are right, but they are also governed by ethics. They want to do the right thing, for the right reasons. They are happy to make personal sacrices to ensure the majority are looked after.It is more important now, than ever, to put people before profits.After three weeks of lockdown, with no chance of a let-up, it’s all too easy to fall prey to catastrophic, even apocalyptic thinking.But we have to sht our thought process. We have to accept and understand that, at some point, this WILL be over.When things are calmer and clearer, we can ask what we can do to ensure we are still operating as the world gets back to normal — whatever the new normal is.The experience we are all living through really is like a storm, which continues to rage.There are so many unprecedented aspects to this situation and there is not one person in the world who will come out of it unchanged.So while there are so many challenging and dficult things going on, perhaps this lockdown is a chance for us all to learn more about ourselves.How are you responding  Have you thought about how you can help others  Have you thought about volunteering for the NHS As well as the importance of good leadership, we all have our inidual roles when it comes to showing autonomy and courage about our own decisions.I’m sorry to say, things are going to get a lot worse before they get better.So we all need to take responsibility — or we will never get out of lockdown.ANYONE who saw the social media video of Naomi Watts reaching breaking point after her printer, vacuum cleaner and dishwasher all broke down will surely have smiled in recognition.Naomi, who has been self-isolating in her Los Angeles home for three weeks, shared her very understandable anguish with a slow-motion video of herself screaming with the sound of a lion’s roar played in the background.I think we can all relate to her frustration.My lockdown revelation I am happy to report that I have given up ironing!WHEN it comes to illness, particularly cancer, I’ve long resisted all the talk of going into battle – mainly because of the unhelpful implication of weakness among those who “lose” that fight by dying.I feel the same way about descriptions of people “fighting” coronavirus.Illness is a fact of le. It is not a sign of weakness.The sad and terrible truth is that some people get this virus and others do not.Some have it very badly – a whole lot worse than others.We don’t yet know exactly why. We don’t even knowwe have the virus and may infect people.We don’t knowthere are antibodies that can protect us from getting it again, or how long that will take.We don’t knowthere will be a more deadly mutation of the same virus in the future.There is just too much we don’t know.But there are some practical things we can do.We need to help those who have it now, and the NHS and the Government are doing all they can in this regard.We also need to stop the spread of the virus, through testing. Hopefully that is going to happen soon.Meanwhile, scientists are also working around the clock to create a vaccine.Perhaps, most of all, we need to prepare for the possibility that this could all happen again.We need to learn lessons on food distribution, working from home, adapting our businesses – and having proper personal protection and hospital equipment ready and waiting.AS time ticks on, we are all realising what le is like without the things we used to consider necessities.Like our hairdressers.Claudia Winkleman’s Instagram post showing how unmanageable her fringe has become during lockdown made me laugh in recognition.My hair is grey, long and unkempt.On the one hand, it’s the least of my worries, which is quite liberating.Still, I did manage to get my hands on some hair dye for the roots.Do I care that it’s completely the wrong shade NO. I do not.So please, can we all just agree to turn a blind eye to the way we look when we finally emerge from lockdown HAPPY Easter Sunday, people. How will you be spending yours Personally, I have lost track of what day it is. The past few weeks have been a blur, with every day feeling like a cross between Sunday and Monday.It was my birthday last week and, without loved ones to hug, friends to see, drinks to be had, it was more or less just another day.Equally, this is the first time ever that Easter has felt like just another weekend.But I hope you can find ways to make it special. Just make sure you do so at home.THERE has been talk of schools possibly reopening after the Easter holidays – and who knows whether or not that is true But one thing I do know is that, whenever they do reopen, working parents will not only give the most massive sigh of relief, they will all be thanking their children’s teachers profusely for everything that they do.We will all also be thanking doctors, nurses, all NHS employees, as well as bin men, cleaners, shop assistants and all the other key workers we have under-paid and taken for granted.I really hope that is one thing which changes as a result of this pandemic.These people are the backbone of our country.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lift coronavirus lockdown debate
story: HAVING been in lockdown for almost three weeks now, the question on everyones lips is when we can go back to our ordinary lives andto normality.We asked two experts to debate the issue. One says that restrictions should be lted sooner rather than later to reboot our ecomony, while the other argues that the restrictions are working, so now is not the right time to lt them.When Chancellor Rishi Sunak first announced his bail-out plan last month, it was estimated that ten to  per cent of workers in the ­private sector would need Government support.Now economic forecasters believe it could be a third of the total private sector workforce. That will cost the British taxpayer between £billion and £billion every three months.To date, about a fth of small businesses have been pushed into bankruptcy. If the lockdown continues to July, that figure will rise to a third.The effect of this on the economy will be catastrophic. According to the ­Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, Britain’s GDP could contract by  per cent over the next two years. It shrank by six per cent during the global financial crisis of -.The Centre for Economics and Business Researchsays the lockdown is costing £.billion a day.Given we are now  days into the lockdown, this means we are already more than £billlion out of pocket.In short,we don’t ease off on the social distancing measures and re-boot the economy, we’re heading for the biggest economic downturn since the s.Against this, we are told thatwe end the lockdown more people will become infected, demand for critical hospital care will outstrip the NHS’s capacity and we’ll begin to see people dying in even greater numbers.I’m sceptical about that prognosis.It is based on the statistical modelling of Professor Neil Ferguson and his team at Imperial College, but there is mounting evidence that they under-estimated the percentage of the population already infected with coronavirus and over-estimated how deadly this disease is.According to Prof Ferguson’s model, fewer than five per cent of people have been infected. But according to another model, this one produced by Oxford University, it could be higher than  per cent, which would mean we are on our way to acquiring herd immunity.When Chris Whitty, England’s Chief Medical Officer, was asked at Thursday’s press conference what percentage of the world’s population has been infected, he put the figure at  per cent.If the true figure is between  and  per cent, the NHS can probably copewe ease off on some of the more extreme social distancing measures.Would ending the lockdown be ­gambling with people’s lives  Yes, but so will keeping it in place.Economic downturns cost lives, just as surely as viruses. During the global financial crisis of –, the suicide rate in Europe increased by . per cent. Economic recessions also cause a rise in poverty, domestic ­violence and murder.Philip Thomas, professor of risk ­management at Bristol University, has calculated thatour GDP falls by more than . per cent as a result of the lockdown, more years of le will be lost than saved.Politicians here and where have justied their cautious approach by ­saying they refuse to put a price on human le, as though the trade-off is between the lives of vulnerable people and economic growth.But the real trade-off is between the lives we might losewe end the ­lockdown tomorrow and the lives we know we will losewe keep it in place indefinitely.MPs aren’t being morally ­courageous. Rather, they’re just focusing on the next -hour news cycle, as they always do.What’s needed is a bold political leader who’s willing to risk some short-term pain to re-start the economy, thereby safeguarding all of our futures.I know of just such a person, but unfortunately he’s in hospital recovering from coronavirus.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealThe UK government’s measures to contain the coronavirus epidemic are just starting to make a ­dference.And with the three-week lockdown under review tomorrow, now is NOT the time to lt them.After a slow and indecisive start, the measures they now have put in place, including recommendations to stay at home, limiting travel, physical ­distancing, banning large gatherings and shutting shops and pubs, are just starting to show signs that they are slowing the spread of the virus.This means that there are fewer new cases, with fewer people becoming seriously sick and less demand on hospital beds, intensive care and articial ventilation.This means that the pressure on health services is reduced, which, in turn, will lead to fewer deaths from Covid- and other causes.Without the actions that have been taken and just letting the epidemic run its course, we would be likely to see more than half the population infected, and an overwhelmed health system with maybe five million hospital admissions and at least , deaths.The measures that have been taken in the UK have been of moderate strength compared to other countries.In France and Spain, the lockdown has been more severe, while in Sweden it has been less strict.The coronavirus epidemic can be thought of like a fire.If we starve a fire of oxygen, then the flames will stop and it will die down.So it is with the epidemic — reduce transmission from person to person and the number of cases will go down.Butyou let the oxygen come back too early, any embers in the fire will light up again and it will restart.So,we relax the lockdown too early, while there is still transmission of the virus going on, then the epidemic will restart.And that means that we would have wasted the efforts we have made so far.When transmission has stopped, or is at low enough levels that it can be monitored and each case and their contacts identied, isolated and treated, then the lockdown can be relaxed.We have not yet reached the peak of the epidemic, and we do not yet have the infrastructure in place for the systematic testing that will be needed to identy new cases, so now is not the time to relax the lockdown measures.Some people have talked about the serious damage done to the economy by measures the Government has put in place and the social disruption these have caused, in order to protect the public health of the nation.They have argued the lockdown will cause more harm than good in the long term. This is a  dilemma.Every le matters. Each person lost is a family member, a friend, a neighbour, a human being.They are not a number on a spreadsheet.This lockdown is the only way for us to get back on our feet.If left uncontrolled, the coronavirus by itself will cause social and economic disruption as well as damaging public health.It doesn’t need any help from politicians.It is up to us all, for the sake of ourselves, our families and our loved ones, to follow the rules, and our solidarity will allow the country totowards normal as soon as possible.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cabinet torn ending coronavirus lockdown
story: CABINET big guns are torn over how and when to end the lockdown now costing Britain £.billion a day.They are trapped in a “lives versus money” row with just  hours to go before the three-week restrictions ordered by Boris Johnson ends.Chancellor Rishi Sunak and Home Secretary Priti Patel are among those who fear the action to halt the spread of coronavirus is worse than the disease.They are pushing for a three-week extension, with an easing of restrictions as early as Monday May .But Health Secretary Matt Hancock and Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove warn this could end the treatment just as it starts to work.They want the lockdown in place for another six weeks from now, to be re-assessed on May  after the Whitsun weekend.A Cabinet source said: “It’s right and proper that we took action. But we must phase it out at the earliest opportunity.It could lead to many more deaths than the virus itself as the economy tanks, people lose jobs and families get poorer and sicker. We need a game plan for ending this.”Caretaker PM Dominic Raab can’t settle the dispute because his role is to chair meetings and carry out his boss’s orders.And with Boris Johnson likely to be away for another three weeks, the government is in danger of becoming rudderless.An insider said: “There’s a bit of a power vacuum. We’re in the middle of a global pandemic and we need him back — but he’s got to be left to rest and get well.”Education Secretary Gavin Williamson fears a longer schools closure will dash the le chances of poor and vulnerable kids.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealMinisters had planned for one in five pupils, the children of key workers, to stay in class yet only two per cent did so.And the Chancellor is shocked that his job retention scheme attracted nine million claims — three times more than he expected.The overall cost to the economy will be nudging £billion by the end of the long Easter weekend.It comes as it is revealed that second home-owners could be eligible for a £, hand-out because of a loophole in the Government’s coronavirus aid scheme.The oversight could put cash into the hands of well-off property owners - and cost the taxpayer billions of pounds.Eventhey agree a date, ministers still have to work out how far to go in ing Britain to normal.Medics and scientists warn that a swtcould lead to a second wave of the virus, with an even more devastating effect.One option is to lt restrictions on dferent regions or sectors. Some are pushing for young people — less prone to serious illness from the virus — toto work first.But a sceptic remarked: “It’s the over-s with the money and experience who are the wealth creators. We need them back soon.”Without a game plan, there are fears that tough limits could still be in place this time next year.The First Secretary of State, Dominic Raab, has rightly said that there is a huge team spirit behind the Prime Minister, willing him on to get back to full health and back where he rightly belongs – leading the Government and our country from  Downing Street.It is important that the business of Government continues at pace during the Prime Minister’s temporary absence from the Downing Street tiller, eventhat is for some time. Decisions, even signicant and dficult decisions, must still be taken by the Cabinet as and when necessary.In this country, we have a system of Government where key decisions are taken by the Cabinet. It is, of course, true that the Prime Minister has signicant personal authority, especially where there is disagreement.However, while the Prime Minister is out of action, his authority will be exercised by Dominic Raab, the First Secretary of State, because he is the Prime Minister’s chosen deputy.Ministers, I am sure, will be very conscious of the fact that it was the Prime Minister who made that choice and he will expect it to be respected. I am sure the Prime Minister will not be amused to read about what has been going on in Cabinet committees in his Sunday newspapers.When the Prime Minister announced the current restrictions on  March, he said this would be reviewed after three weeks. The time for this review is next week.Given we are yet to reach the peak of the virus, I am quite sure that next week the Government will formally decide that the current restrictions will have to stay in place for another three weeks into May.The data on the number of new cases is starting to suggest that the current social distancing measures are working but continuing with them for another period is necessary to ensure we protect the NHS and save lives.That’s why people need to continue to stay at home over the Easter weekend, apart from the four allowed exceptions. Thinking about the future, we will only be able toto something like normal le once we have created a vaccine.This is likely to take somewhere between - months and so, in the meantime, we will need a recovery plan that continues to protect the health of the nation whilst allowing us to get the economy going again.The Government must work on that recovery plan at pace whilst it continues with the current restrictions and it must also be as open as possible with the public about what that plan will look like as and when the pieces are put into place. There are three reasons for this.First, whilst the vast majority of the population has been doing a fantastic job complying with the rules so far, the longer the restrictions are in place, the more likely we are to continue this level of compliancethe public can see the light at the end of the tunnel.Second, over the coming days and weeks, the many people in our country who are self-employed or who run larger companies are going to need to take decisions about the future of their businesses.So we need to give them as much information as we can, as soon as we can, about the future so they are prepared to take the calculated risks necessary to keep their businesses going. That’s vitally importantwe’re going to minimise the economic cost of defeating this virus.Finally, any recovery plan is likely to involve a signicant volume of testing, with contact tracing and perhaps the use of technology seen in countries like South Korea to ensure any resurgence of virus can be dealt with swtly.As we have seen from the challenges facing the Government on testing for NHS frontline staff, it takes time to get this capacity in place.We need to make sure than when the Government is confident that the evidence is in place to allow a relaxation of the current measures, our testing capability, and all that goes with it, is ready to be rolled out quickly.I am confident that the Cabinet, led by the First Secretary of State Dominic Raab in the Prime Minister’s absence, will continue working hard and making the necessary decisions when they need to be made so that the PM, upon histo health, can hit the ground running and, as the Prime Minister’s great hero Sir Winston Churchill would say, take “action this day”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gordon ramsay cornwall holiday home coronavirus parking
story: GORDON Ramsay has reportedly been caught in a row over his x after the chef was slammed for moving his family to Cornwall during the coronavirus lockdown. Pictures show a shopper appearing to give the TV star a telling off after he was reportedly left unhappy about the way the chefs Land Rover Defender was parked.Gordon, , was previously slammed by locals after he quit London to move to his £million mansion to wait out the coronavirus pandemic.Witnesses said the row occurred near Polzeath Beach and added the chef kept his cool throughout the dispute on Friday, April .The other man - carrying a Tesco bag - confronted Gordon about the size and parking of the shiny black Land Rover, reports MailOnline.Pictures show the man gesturing towards the Kitchen Nightmares star - who can seen over the roof of the x.The man then walked off and the TV chef could be seen getting into his car with a bag of shopping and a coffee.It comes as locals in the West Country have called for action to be taken on people fleeing to their holiday homes to beat the pandemic.Second home owners and holidaymakers have been accused of sneaking into the area and potentially bringing the virus with them.Local authorities asked for road blocks to stop people flooding towards tourist hotspots.Britain basked in sunshine over this weekend, and numerous people seen flouting isolation guidelines to enjoy the weather - including in Cornwall.Furious villagers have threatened to hound the Hells Kitchen star out of Cornwall.Gordon moved down with his we Tana and five kids to isolate from the coronavirus by the sea.Neighbours feared the family - who moved from London - may have risked spreading the infection.London remains the worst impacted city in the UK for the virus.The Sun revealed members of a Facebook group called You Shouldn’t Be Here have threatened to expose Gordon’s addresshe does not leave.One said: “The big s*** should take himself and his family the hell out of Cornwall.”Others accused the Scot of ignoring Government advice by not staying at his primary location.They claimed: “He’s swanning around the shops asnothing is wrong.“He’s had pool engineers over.There is no defence at all.”Another added: “Wealthy second homers think making a few quid means they are immune from the virus and any rules.They are arrogant at this best of times, this has shown how bad some of them are.”The family — including one-year-old Oscar — have been staying on the Cornish coast since restrictions began.Pals however have hit back - claiming he regards the property as his family home.A friend called the complaints hurtful and an unnecessary campaign against the the family.One friend told the : The family see Cornwall as their family home when the kids are back from uni and Gordon back from filming around the world.It’s where they spend all their family time together, they’ve been spending time there for  years and Jack actually lives in the house there full time too.Most of their neighbours are so welcoming and they love being part of the community.They’ve been following the government advice, along with the rest of the country, since they arrived on March .The campaign against them is hurtful and unnecessary at a time when we should all be coming together and supporting each other.Gordon has also come under fire for laying off  employees as he was forced to close his London restaurants due to the pandemic.Chefs, waiters and other staff were reportedly summoned into a meeting and told their contracts were being terminated.They were later sent an email explaining they would only be paid up to April .In a post on Facebook, chef Anca Torpuc blasted the celeb - title: andrea bocelli tears mesmerising easter concert empty milan cathedral
story: OPERA legend Andrea Bocelli left fans across the globe in tears with a mesmerising performance at the empty Duomo cathedral in Milan.An incredible . million people tuned in to watch the singers Music for Hope concert, which sent a message of love, healing and hope to Italy and the rest of the world in the grip of the coronavirus crisis.️Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAlthough the famous Duomo cathedral is shut due to the pandemic, Bocelli was granted exclusive access by Milan Mayor Giuseppe Sala and Archpriest Monsignor Gianantonio Borgonovo.He was accompanied by the cathedrals organist Emanuele Vianelli, and performed a selection of pieces including Ave Maria and Amazing Grace.Bocelli, one of the worlds most famous tenor singers, hoped to bring people together through the concert which he described as more of a prayer than a performance.Viewers flocked to social media in awe of Bocellis performance, which was livestreamed on his YouTube channel at pm.One user wrote: Hearing @AndreaBocelli always gives me chills and brings tears to my eyes. His voice is so powerful!And another added: @AndreaBocelli you touched my heart. I cried tears for Italy and the entire world.Italy has been ravaged by the coronavirus, with , deaths and over , infected.But the countrys fatality rate has recently started to fall, with deaths rising by  on Sunday, down from  the day before.The figure is the lowest daily death toll recorded in the country since March  - offering Italians a glimmer of hope that the peak of the epidemic may have passed.The daily rise of coronavirus cases in the country also slowed to , from a previous ,.Bocelli, , has also started a fundraiser to help hospitals purchase protective equipment for medical staff during the pandemic, which has so far raised €,.Speaking ahead of his performance, he said he was honoured to perform for the city of Milan and the Italian people.He said: I believe in the strength of praying together I believe in the Christian Easter, a universal symbol of rebirth that everyone – whether they are believers or not – truly needs right now.Thanks to music, streamed live, bringing together millions of clasped hands everywhere in the world, we will hug this wounded Earths pulsing heart, this wonderful international forge that is reason for Italian pride.This morning, the Italian premier Giuseppe Conte marked Easter Sunday by thanking people for their sacrices in fighting the virus.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.He also acknowledged that many families are suffering the loss of loved ones as they celebrate Easter with empty places at the table.“Together, we will make it,” Mr Conte said in a Facebook post.Officials also noted that Italy has increased its testing capacity in recent days, yielding more positive cases but allowing for more effective quarantine measures for people once they know they are infected. Italy crossed the one million virus test mark on Sunday, doubling the number of tests since the end of March.And Italy is now looking at plans to ease lockdown restrictions – despite health experts warning it would be a “dangerous thing to do”.Shops and businesses could reopen on April , and Italians could be allowed to go outside andto work from May , it is reported. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: clean food shop dr hilary coronavirus
story: Dr Hilary Jones – health editor for ITV’s Good Morning Britain and Lorraine – is The Sun’s go-to expert to answer any concerns or worries you may have regarding coronavirus.Thousands of you have read his clear and concise answers which cut through the confusion of coronavirus and contacted us with questions you would like to put to the doctor.Today, he tells Emma Pietras who is more at risk to the virus, how to keep safe outdoors and what to do about vulnerable relatives.Q. I have a hole in my heart and an enlarged heart. Whenever I get the flu or colds, it goes straight to my chest. Am I more vulnerable to coronavirus A. Yes. You are more vulnerable with any form of heart disease and you need to stay home, socially distance and wash your hands regularly.Q. I have a regular B injection. Am I more vulnerable A. Having regular vitamin B injections will not make you more vulnerable nor will any underlying medical condition, which has caused B deficiency.Q. How can you keep safe when going shopping A. Try to do it infrequently and don’t travel too far. If there is a queue stand two metres away from everyone  and keep your distance from the checkout. You can still be sociable and polite. Try to choose shops where the staff are wearing protective equipment. When you get home, throw away packaging and wash your hands. Q. Should I use antiseptic wipes on my food shop when I unpack A. Antiseptic wipes only have a very weak effect on bugs and germs on packaging. For cleaning the virus from surfaces you really need a chlorine-based cleaning product, such as bleach. For your hands, use a product containing rubbing alcohol of at least  per cent strength.Q. Is it safe to continue to take fluticasone nasal drops and nitro-furantoin capsules I have been prescribed  I am concerned they could weaken my immune system.A. While the nasal drops are steroids which reduce inflammation they only act locally. The nitrofurantoin anti- biotics will make no dference whatsoever. You should continue to use your medication as the benefits are far greater than the risks.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealQ. My partner is terminally ill and I have diabetes. I am a key worker. Should I self-isolate for  weeks A. What awful decisions so many of us have to make. While your husband is in the high risk group, you are categorised in the vulnerable group and you should work from homeyou can and keep a physical distance from others.Key workers may continue to work under the current guidance but you need to take extra-special care of yourself. You could also ask your bossyou can work in a non public-facing role.Q. I work in the NHS in a child development centre. One of the nurses advised to shower and change my clothes at home because my husband has an autoimmune condition. Is this really necessary A. I think going to these s is unnecessary unless you are a healthcare professional exposed to high levels of risk, seeing potentially in-fected patients.If you are washing your hands regularly you will not be transmitting any virus from clothes or hair to your face this should be sufficient.Q. I’m , a diabetic on insulin and a key worker. Should I be working A. Diabetes puts you into the more vulnerable group being advised to work from homepossible. Key workers, however, are an exception and while you can still go to work it is worth askingyour role can be adapted so you are not in a public facing role.Practice very strict personal hygiene too. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: house of commons sit remotely
story: THE House of Commons could sit next week entirely via remote with the Speaker as the only person in the chamber, The Sun can reveal.It was confirmed yesterday that Parliament willnext Tuesday, April , as planned.But with the coronavirus epidemic still raging, “technological solutions” are being drawn up to allow MPs to abide by lockdown guidelines.Under one option being studied by the Government now, ministers could take questions from MPs via video conferencing.Neither inquisitor nor responder would have to be in the chamber, The Sun has been told, including for PMQs.Only Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle will remain in his chair to preside, served by a bank of TV screens wheeled in front of him.A senior Commons source said: “A motion could be passed that would allow even the Speaker to be remote, but it’s unlikely he will favour this option.”The options are still being worked up by Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg for a decision this week.Mr Rees-Mogg’s spokeswoman said: “Parliament willon st April to fulfil its essential constitutional s of conducting scrutiny, authorising spending and making laws.“In these unprecedented times, technological solutions have already been implemented for select committee and options are being prepared for the Speaker, the government and other parties to consider next week.“It is important that we have a comprehensive solution that does not inadvertently exclude any members.”A small number of MPs would have to come into Parliament for a single day to vote through the changes.Debate is still raging on how MPs should vote, with concern about the security of any system of doing it online.Commons committees are already taking evidence remotely via video, with only the committee chairs sitting in Parliament’s evidence rooms.Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer added: “It’s very important in a crisis like this that ministers can be scrutinised. title: china cash in coronavirus
story: THIS time last week, along with the rest of Fleet Street, I was writing Boris Johnson’s obituary.China had killed our Prime Minister, I said. I’ve never been so pleased to see my copy spiked.We now know from the PM himself just how close he came to death. But had things turned out dferently, my first sentence would still ring true.Boris would have paid the ultimate price for Covid-.The killer virus was spawned in China’s primitive “wet markets” and concealed by the country’s secretive communist regime and blamed by China on America and the West.Beijing’s claim of only , dead is a sick joke. The true figure could be ten times as high — or more.This, remember, is the regime that still lies about the thousands slaughtered in the  Tiananmen Square massacre.Yet China, having destroyed lives and livelihoods around the globe, is emerging as the big winner from its own pandemic.Like vultures hovering over roadkill, leaders of the world’s second-biggest economy are eyeing up the casualties of this made in-China calamity.Covid- risks opening the door to Beijing’s dominance over world trade and commerce, at unimaginable cost to our freedoms and democracy.Rattled world leaders, from Australia to Germany, are drafting emergency laws to prevent China mopping up crown jewels in pharmaceuticals, minerals, articial intelligence and robot technology.But it is probably too late. The West has turned a blind eye to China’s decades of industrial espionage and its cut-price grab for market share.Germany, Europe’s largest economy, is utterly dependent on cheap, heavily subsidised Chinese components and the VW and Mercedes car sales that account for a third of their profits.Suicidally, it will see Chinese cash as a passport out of the crisis.“We have grown too idle and too comfortable to want to do the things the Chinese do for us,” says a Cabinet insider.The world stood silent as China’s Belt And Road programme gobbled up key ports and industries, rare earth minerals and rich farmland across Africa and the Third World.Beijing is now rubbing its hands at the prospect of fresh bargains.Household-name firms here and in Europe are struggling to survive the lockdown. Some will never reopen their doors.The best might end up in Beijing at fire-sale prices.China has already seized a big stake in the UK with its richly subsidised £billion contract for the Hinkley Point nuclear power station in Somerset.Telecoms giant Huawei has its sticky fingers all over our sensitive G superhighway — a decision which must now surely be reversed.The image of communist China as a civilised equal partner is a dangerous fantasy.“China is not and never will be our friend,” a senior minister warns. “But it is the only one with ready cash and all our markets have collapsed because of something China started.“Our economy is being shattered and it is their fault. The idea of selling them some of our best companies is horrying.”China’s own economy has been hammered too. But it remains a ruthless totalitarian state which brooks no opposition.The brutal incarceration of a million Uighur Muslims in “re-education” camps is a blot on the civilised world. So is the trade in human organs from executed prisoners.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealWho will stop China becoming the world’s dominant power It will be hard for our liberal elite to swallow, but the only answer is Donald Trump.The American President has already cracked down on China’s trade and currency cheating. Democrat rival Joe Biden — backed by peace-at-any-price Barack Obama — would kowtow to Beijing.At this pivotal moment in world history, it is reassuring to know President Trump has a high regard for our Prime Minister.Once Boris is back on his feet and coronavirus begins to fade, he must join forces with the world’s greatest superpower and address the smiling menace of Chinese President Xi Jinping.As the saying goes, what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger.Boris was hardest hit, followed by chief of staff Dominic Cummings, who is only now ing to work after a fortnight in bed.A dozen others, including Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty and No Press chief Lee Cain, went down like skittles.So who was the super-spreader The finger of suspicion is pointed at health supremo Matt Hancock, first in and energetically first out of self- isolation. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: large wildcat spotted cambridgeshire fen tiger returns
story: According to legend, the Fen Tiger has been on the prowl in Cambs and beyond for more than  years, with a number of sightings reported across the county.The latest sighting was recorded near Coldhams Lane, Cambs, on Saturday where the cat was said to be as big as a fully grown Labrador.A resident who lives in the area said he believed it was looking for small animals to eat around his property.He added that the cat had visited in the past, but this time he was able to capture it on camera.He told Cambridgeshire Live: It was around  or .am this morning when I saw the animal from my kitchen window.Initially I thought it was a wildcat like a Felis Silvestris, but then I went to my colleagues at the university and they said it cant have been as this animal was way bigger.The animal was a brown and black colour with a very long tail that had lots of black circles on it. The tail was so long, and its legs were thick as well with big claws.I think it somehow keeps coming to this place to hunt rabbits or other small animals.It was about the size of a fully grown Labrador dog.When asked whether or not the animal could have been the Fen Tiger the man added: I have heard about the mystery of the Fen Tiger but I dont knowthis was it.This was a wild cat like people have said the Fen Tiger is and this one is the size of a Labrador dog.The theory that Britain has an elusive population of wild big cats has proved enduring, with many people reporting sightings in rural areas.Last year, a wildcat expert revealed there had been five confirmed sightings of pumas in the UK, warning a population of around  were breeding across the country.Rick Minter, Britains leading big cat tracker, said he had seen conclusive videos of the animals amid estimates that hundreds have made the UK their home.In August, a photographer claimed to see a dog-sized cat prowling around the Yorkshire countryside.John Pearson, , was taking pictures at St Aidans Nature Reserve near Leeds when the mysterious creature caught his eye.And last April, a Labrador-sized feline was filmed prowling a field near a Cotswolds pub as police and the RSPCA told of a hamlet in Cornwall where pets have vanished is being stalked by a large panther-like animal.Several people claim to have seen the Beast of Ossett which has been spotted prowling in the woodland and fields around the West Yorkshire town.There have also been a number of alleged sightings of the Wildcat of the Wolds near Drfield, East Riding, Yorkshire, where incidents of mutilated livestock were reported as well.Back in , Lee Clford thought he had captured a photograph of a wildcat roaming the countryside near Hull.

title: where chequers prime minister residence
story: The residence will play host to Boris Johnson as he continues to recover from coronavirus after he was discharged from hospital on Easter Sunday.Chequers is a country house near the village of Ellesborough in Buckinghamshire at the foot of the Chiltern Hills.The mansion is about  miles from Downing Street.It is a Grade One listed building used by the Prime Minister as a country home outside Westminster.David Lloyd George was the first PM to use it.No. Despite being at the centre of British government, very few members of the public have ever seen it as its not open to the public.Chequers, or Chequers Court, dates back to th century.The name Chequers is said to derive from an early owner of the manor of Ellesborough in the th century, Elias Ostiarius .The name Ostiarius meant an usher of the Court of the Exchequer and scacchiera means a chess board in Italian.Elias Ostiarius coat of arms included the chequer board of the Exchequer, so it is possible the estate is Mr Hancock said in a commitment to transparency, the source code will be published, and he sought to reassure people that data will not be held any longer than is necessary. His worried we Gerry cared for him at their home after the retired microbiologist refused to take him to hospital. She hasnapost caught the deadly virus but recorded the full experience for them both in a diary which was originally written for a Covid- Cheltenham page on Facebook.Paul, , told Gloucestershire Live : “It was like being hit by a train. You lose all your energy. You’re burning up all the time.“You just have to fight your way through it. Mentally, there were times when I was very low.” Paul has lost a stone and a half in weight since first developing symptoms of the disease on March . He added: “Generally speaking, I’m feeling pretty good. But I go for a walk every afternoon and after about  minutes, I get breathless.“I’m still a long way from being back to the level I was at. I think it will be another two weeks, at least.    Paul’s Covid- story, through Gerry’s diary Just want to say my husband, who is , fit and healthy caught the virus in Derby when he was on contract work. I am , asthmatic, and high risk, so what a dilemma, me looking after him. Day  : Paul came home from work yesterday. At first the symptoms were mild, no cough more like a cold, and we both thought that’s good, but I think I had better sleep in the spare bedroom just in case. At this point I should tell you I am an ex microbiologist, albeit many years ago, I have also worked in a cardiac unit, and then went into digital medical imaging for a couple of companies, training doctors in telemedicine and PACS which was new to the NHS then.Day  : He worked at home, eating normally and drinking wine with a meal, his temperature was slightly rising, but he said he didn’t feel that bad, slept well.Day  : Woke up and said he was feeling much better, so worked from home again, we ate a good lunch and I thought Ok mild symptoms just like they said. That night on the sofa he said I don’t feel good, then WHAM, he said it was like being hit with a hot wrecking ball. He went up to bed about pm, he looked bad, red eyed, ruddy face, shivering but hot and clammy, didn’t want any supper. Unlike Paul as he loved his food. Day  : Now in bed all the time, temperature rising from .- , he says he feels awful, he looks awful, I am not too worried at the moment, as I had had Hong Kong flu in  and know what a virus can do to your body, plus several chest infects and pneumonia twice, and as an asthmatic, I cannot get this new virus. Paul needs me as well.I keep the fluids going for him by filling water jugs and trying to get him to drink, not easy when all he wants to do is sleep. In my head I set about a new cleaning regime, even though I had adhered to government advice and washed hands, and wiped down surfaces with antibac wipes, I was going to go even further. I am symptomless at the moment. Day  : Still no cough, but very high temperatures, complete exhaustion, loss of appetite, tired was not the word, it was assleep had overcome him. But we only have one bathroom, which proved dficult.Food was not too much of a problem as he only ate two Weetabix a day, but getting him to drink and take paracetamol was not easy with a person who only wanted to sleep. I am his carer now and I am determined to get him better and not to go into hospital. Would he ever come out Day  : I am not getting much sleep as now as I am beginning to worry, we are being told by the government symptoms are mild and after  days of isolation you can go out. WHAT we are on day  and he just about can get out of bed to go to the toilet.BANG his temperature went up above . Paracetamol every  hours is not having much effect. I keep telling him to drink, and sit up as I know this virus attacks your lungs so completely lying down is no good, but he yells at me he just wants to sleep, I am in despair. Neighbours are supplying us with food basics, and I have to stay in as I am high risk, that is a joke, he was fit and healthy, he has it I don’t yet, still no symptoms for me. Day  : Cough intermittent. Now, temperature -  not eaten anything today, that’s ok he was overweight, so not worried about that. Loss of taste, and smell, tea he said tasted like sick, he doesn’t want tea now, or coffee. Wow this is a very dferent virus. His eyes sore and red and looks dreadful, ruddy face get ruddier and clearly very very unwell. Still won’t sit up.This is a game changer, I must get him to drink as I notice his urine is quite dark, I am feeling isolated, which is what I am, but isolated with a sick man who is my husband. I need a drink, I open up some prosecco from the fridge, oh Paul normally does the cork bit, never mind I can do that.  Those  glasses were great. My only outing has been walking my dog Dylan, which is like winning the lottery every time I go out, walking, aside whenever I see someone  walk by, chats from a distance, not many people these days, and no cars. So dferent to last week when the Cheltenham festival was on, Southam Lane was packed full of cars, and you can see the racecourse screens from my bedroom window, and hear the loud speakers, everything is quiet there now, only the birds singing. Oh was that a plane I can see in the sky  Day   : Pretty much the same as yesterday. High temperature, very high still, ruddy face, chills but hot, loss of taste and smell more pronounced as the Weetabix needed more sugar on it, although I had put some, no loads, on it.He hadn’t been speaking to me much except to ask for water, or orange juice or his Weetabix, I noticed he hadn’t been using his phone for a few days, so unlike Paul as his phone was an extension of his right arm, he is sinking into depression I thought, he had been depressed before, he said the darkness overtook him, and was on Prozac for  months, is that happening now  He was also angry, angry with me and himself. He told me he didn’t know why he couldn’t control the virus, why was he not getting any better  What can I do to make him better  Yes Paul is a bit of a control freak, but he says so am I. I asked him to sit up. I can’t he says, it’s not comfortable, I want to sleep now. So I go out of the room and watch the news. Yes I had been avidly watching the daily briefings, depressing, hope gone out for many, lockdown a new word, more deaths in Italy, oh those pictures in the Italian hospital made me think this could happen here. Then there was the government still saying most will get it mild, for  days. So in my head I am thinking you either get mild symptoms for  days or die. Death was everywhere, headlines. This deadly virus, how many had died today, how many had caught it, was there nothing in between mild and death  Then when I told my friends Paul was very ill, I suspected it was Covid-, most said ‘So sorry, poor you.’ It was just like being back in the ’s when someone told someone  they had Aids, it was a death sentence. So Covid- was a death sentenceyou didn’t get it mild, and although most deaths were those with underlying conditions, mostly elderly, the media were now highlighting fit and healthy young people had died. Day  : It was about pm and his temperature climbed to over , and said he could not take a deep breath and when I looked at him I could see fear in eyes, that is when I phoned , yes it took ages to get through, but I hung on, describing symptoms,  nswering their questions, they said yes, it probably was Covid, but was then told a doctor would be calling.Doctor called back and was . per cent sure it was Covid, he said he was not worried about the high temperature, as that was his body fighting this awful virus, but he did tell Paul, you will get over this, you are fit. Advice was sit up in bed, move aroundyou can, drink as much as you can, and get better. If you need more help you can phone your surgery. That was enough for him to let go of the fear in his head. Day  : Paul is still very ill, temperature still high, and so so weak, he could hardly stand, but he wanted clean sheets on his bed. My microbiology brain came zooming in, ‘Paul you will have to take them downstairs yourself and put them in the washing machine.’ He didn’t know how to change the temperature so I did that, they got washed at  degrees, then hung out on the line.Goodbye you horrible coronaviruses on my sheets. The new sheets I could do, and he was happy now the feel of , thread count fresh cotton sheets would make anyone feel better. Although sitting up more it was in short periods, and every time I asked him to sit up, he said aposstop nagging meapos, Was he getting better  Not sure as he was still sleeping loads. Day  : Neighbours still bringing supplies to my doorstep, I had three separate neighbours bring me ious basics. How weird! but wonderful, what great neighbours I have. Paul had suddenly asked for orange juice, so that was delivered to our doorstep along with some bread, eggs and milk, and oh yes some choccy biscuits ,and I have managed to get our local dairies to deliver Milk and other dairy products next week, that will be so good. I also ordered some Wine from MS, havenapost had red wine now for a week, only the Proseco left over from the Panto in January, The Wizard of Gloz. Thinking I could do with a wizard now to magic this bloody virus to hell. Anyway my red wine should have been delivered by now, where on earth is it  Still can’t get a food delivery slot, have been trying now for ages. Today I also stopped watching and listening to the news, just going to listen to the daily broadcast on Sky by the PM and the chief medical officer. I am big radio fan , Radio  live and Radio , but so many opposition politicians blaming the government for this, just would like to know what they would have done dferent, damn those politicians. Just Radio  now, Rylan on Saturday was so funny with his best ever worst jokes, I was laughing so much I almost forgot I had a sick husband upstairs. I am also a quilter, so making a spiderman quilt for my  year old grandson was a great distraction as well. Who would have thought Spiderman and Rylan would be so comforting on a sunny Saturday. Isolation, not good. Paul’s temperature now , and I have been running up and downstairs so often now, I am feeling quite fit for a -year-old at high risk. Now pm, Paul sleeping, I can have some me time downstairs with some more Prosecco, Dylan on the sofa as normal fast asleep, I normally don’t go to bed till after , so I watched Ghosts on catchup. Hilarious, made me laugh so much, but weird thinking a programme about dead people would make me feel happy with laughter. Time for bed. I stand beside his bed, bedside cabinets strewn with empty paracetamol packets, thermometer, two empty glasses, a jug half empty, I wonder how many virus bits are on those. I quietly put them in a bag and take the downstairs to the dishwasher, I then scrub my hands for  seconds in hot water. Today I washed his towels at  degrees. Back up stairs to hopefully sleep undisturbed. Tonight was the first night I felt I wouldn’t keep looking in on him to seehe was ok, a bit like a sick child. Day  : He is much better today, temperature virtually down to normal, but very very weak. Eating more but we both can see the light at the end of the tunnel. I have so many great comments from the Facebook page it has been so comforting, that so many others are going through the same thing, and that we are all scared, all in the same boat with this virus swimming alongside us.I am pleased I can help some, and advise where possible, over , likes and comments now. Similar symptoms, especially the taste and smell thing, I am so pleased I did this, I just hope it will have a happy ending. I just want to thank those neighbours who have helped with shopping,you are reading this, thanks Ruth, Matt and Steph, and Robbie. I hope this diary will give hope to those in despair that they think they will not get better, as most of us will, and this virus, as I have just heard the PM has it, doesnapost care who it settles on. So everyone stay safe and be positive, as I have seen at first hand the mental side of this is just as damaging as the physical side of this disease.  Day  : Thank you all for your kind words during this dficult time, just for those who don’t know.I started writing this as the government are saying most have mild symptoms, and after  days you can stop self isolating, as Boris and Mat said yesterday, the other extreme seemed to be death. As this is our personal case and yesterday we were in day , there did not seem to be anything in between, so I diarised Paul Covid- illness. Most of you know me as the script writer of our amdram pantos, the last one being the Wizard of Gloz at Prestbury Hall in January in aid of James Hopkins Trust in Gloucester, and also to give the villages of Prestbury, Woodmancote and Southam some fun and laughter, so I have had to resist saying Oh no he isn’t and He’s behind you in this diary. Many of you have asked how I am feeling. So how am I feeling  Lonely at times, exhausted running up and down stairs with drinks and food, but blessed I have some great and wonderful neighbours. It is almost like looking after a very obstreperous sick child. But most of all worried, about Paul, and about whether he is still infectious, the government say  days and  daysboth are infected. As an ex microbiologist, my scientic brain wants to know these answers, and why some of the symptoms we are all experiencing are not included in the info. Paul did eat better, but still wants to sleep flat, against doctor’s advice, so this morning he told me he went down stairs as he felt he could not get enough oxygen in his lungs, so sat on the sofa. He also opened a large brown packet that he thought was a new cereal, only to find that with milk it tasted awful - no wonder, it was dried yeast flakes for bread making. This morning still lying down in bed complaining he couldn’t breathe, which is worrying, but obviously part of the disease, but telling him to sit up was frustrating. So I asked him to explain more. How it felt, he said, was that he felt stuffed in his lungs, which is how I sometimes feel being an asthmatic. So I have a nebuliser at home, with some Ventolin solution and saline solution for use with the nebuliser. Although not an asthmatic, I did give him the Ventolin on the nebuliser. I have to stress this was NOT done on medical advice, but my own personal advice. Afterwards he said he felt his airways had opened, which is exactly what nebulised Ventolin does. I will probably get into medical trouble for telling you this, but I was onl  going on his symptoms, which as an ex microbiologist we used to in the s and s, no modelling graphs then. Oh I must stop saying what I think.  I also have one of those little pressure metal inhalers, and a salt pipe for use when I am bad, with asthma, which I have given him. Stuffed lungs or not stuffed lungs, seems to me I made the correct choice,not medical decision. His temperature remains about ., which is better than . It is now about .pm. I have showered got dressed and put my makeup on, can’t be seen without my brows done, mascara on and lipstick, you never know who is going to see you through the front door window. Many of you have asked how I have kept symptom free. Seeing bacteria under the microscope and in poo, sick urine e.t.c. I have always loved bleach in the bathroom, and have at least two bottles handy near the loo, Paul doesn’t seem to know they exist, and as a man always leaves the loo seat up. So I have torn some paper up and use this to close it, I am spraying it with mould destroyer regularly, contains bleach, as I would like to keep my antibacterial wipes for door handles, and bleach for inside the loo. I may go over the top on some things, butI take his plates and cups downstairs, I put them in a bag, with my latex gloves on, then straight into the dishwasher. Clothes bedsheets, I have asked him to put in the washing machine and put the soap capsule in, he didnapost know how to use the increased temperature button, so I do that and wash sheets and towels at  degrees and his clothes at  degrees, toughthey shrink. I wipe down all door handles and taps at night before bed and I have bought some sterilising tablets from amazon to keep his toothbrush free of germs. Our electric toothbrush is moow just his, as he has to handle it regularly I use my travel toothbrush. I am not a doctor remember, but I do expect some medical professional to have a go at me for giving him the Ventolin, but I don’t care, it worked for him and he is my husband. It is now nearly pm, and Paul says although weak still does feel better. Day  ½ over. I do wish Boris our PM, Matt Hancock and Chris, the chief medical officer a speedy recovery and do hope their mild symptoms don’t get any worse as in what we have experienced here. Hope you all stay safe and well and enjoy your free time, remain positive andyou need medical help ask , but do hang in there. As dory says, keep on swimming.

Ky Frost spotted Joe Bakowski in a predicament at the checkout of a Sainsburyaposs in Oadby, Leicestershire this weekend. The -year-old realised that he had forgotten his wallet when she saw him patting his pockets, Leicestershire Live reported. Ky, a nursery nurse, walked over after hearing Joe explain how he left his wallet at home to the cashier, and offered to pay for him. Do you know a coronavirus hero  Get in touch with your story at  webnews@mirror Joe, who repaid the cash a short time later, was incredibly touched by her random act of kindness. He wrote: Queuing outside in the sunshine, it was great to see the Sainsbury’s team working away calmly and professionally, but sharing a laugh with the queuing customers, too. A young lady who had just finished at the next checkout immediately offered to pay for me – well over £ – despite not knowing me from Adam. Not only that, she then waited around, with her young child, while I ran my parents’ and my uncle’s shopping through, too, and paid for that as well. Since the virus began edging its way towards the UK public health officials have warned that new, persistent coughs and fevers are tell-tale signs of the disease. While it has not been listed as an official symptom to watch out for, many people have posted online about experiencing a aposfizzingapos sensation. Dr Vipul Shah, Clinical Director at telehealth service Pack Health, suggested it may simply be people experiencing a fever for the first time.Another mild symptom of coronavirus that is being reported with increased regularity is the need to go to the toilet more often. Dr Diana Gall explained to the Express : Digestion problems and changes in bowel habits - particularly looser stools and making more frequent trips to the toilet - are sometimes the first signs that you’re coming down with something, not just with this coronavirus. However, diarrhoea has been reported as an early symptom in patients who have later tested positive for Covid-. A new study, published in the American Journal of Gastroenterology, analysed data  patients with Covid- in China’s Hubei province and found nearly  per cent had diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain. Isla Haslam, , from Balham, South West London, experienced stomach problems while suffering with the coronavirus. title: gordon ramsay explains youre cooking
story: NewsGordon Ramsay explains why youre cooking burgers wrong - and how to do it rightGordon Ramsay explains how to make the "perfect" burger in no time at allShareCommentsByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  APR NewsGordons perfect burger recipe has been viewed over  million times" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritain might be in lockdown but those lucky enough to have a garden have been dusting down their barbecues for a garden feast. Out come the burgers, hot dogs, sausages, chicken legs, fish and tasty char-grilled veg, all cooked in the sunshine. Most homes have a designated BBQ chef, who has their own special way of cooking outside - but Gordon Ramsay says theyaposre doing it all wrong. And since he owns a burger restaurant in Las Vegas he obviously knows what heaposs talking about. In a video viewed more than million times, Gordon explains not only how to make the perfect patty but all of the most common mistakes we make and how to avoid them. Gordon said: This is one of my most desired burgers, one of my favourite burgers and then goes on to mention that this burger is on sale at his burger restaurant in Planet Hollywood, Las Vegas, and is known as the F-Word burger. Use dferent meats Gordon explains that the secret behind a perfect burger is a mixture of dferent quality meats. He uses chuck, as well as ground beef and brisket. Preparation is key Gordon generously seasons the meat with salt and pepper and binds it altogether using a touch of egg. He says you canapost season the burgers after theyaposre cooked so he makes sure to roll the seasoning around the edge of the burger too. But says this should be done the day beforepossible, then you need to set them in the fridge so they stay nice and firm and donapost fall apart on the grill. And when it comes to cooking the bruegrs, donapost put them straight onto the heat from the fridge because then theyaposll be dry on the outside and raw in the middle. Drizzle a little olive oil onto them too - he uses grapeseed oil.  Put the BBQ lid down When you place the burgers onto the grill it should be piping hot and you should place them onto the hottest part - which is usually two thirds of the way up. When youaposve placed the burgers on the grill Gordon explains: The secret is to move it as less as possible. The more you move it, the more chance youaposve got of breaking the burger. Make sure to put the BBQ lid down once your burgers are in as this incorporates the heat, and gets a great sear on the bottom, so when we come to turn those burgers they donapost stick. How many times have you stuck burgers on the grill and wondered why itaposs sticking  Nicely oiled, quick sear and put that lid down - itaposs really important.  Toasting the buns Once the burgers are cooking the next step is to toast the buns. Gordon says We toast the buns because thereaposs nothing worse than a soggy bun. Toasting the bun makes them nice and crisp, and it protects the burger. He seasons the buns with salt, pepper and a drizzle of oil, before putting them on the grill and closing the lid again. And even toasts the tops of the bun too.  Get set up Gordon ensures that the rest of his ingredients are prepped, ready for when the burgers are cooked - they only take three to four minutes each side to cook completely. Tomatoes and lettuce are chopped, and the onions are on the grill cooking. He said: This is a really important tip. Why  It stops the burgers going cold - you want to at it when itaposs piping hot.  Adding butter Approximately two minutes before the burgers are ready to come off, Gordon adds butter. Gordon says: “Now at my burger restaurant in Las Vegas, we baste the burgers with Devonshire butter. “Today, we’re going to lightly brush a bit of butter onto the burgers. “With that flame underneath, it caramelises the butter and puts this wonderful flavour on top. “It makes the burgers so tasty.” He also suggests making a red-wine butter or a chipotle butteryou want to be even more chefy. And lightly season them again with salt and pepper.
